args: Please note that this story contains spoilers\nfor Chapter 19 of the main campaign.
Hmm? What brings you here?\nYou know I have the watch tonight.
...Trouble sleeping, eh? Well, perhaps\none of my old stories will help.
I don't believe I've told you just who\nSheila and I are.
If we're to continue working together—\nas I hope we do—it seems only prudent\nto reveal a bit about us.
So pray, lend me your ear awhile.\nThis begins a dozen-odd years ago,\nwhen I was a king...
Several years ago\nNorth Grastaea\nKingdom of Lefkos
＂My dear friend Aurelius,\nThough the calendar claims it is spring,\nthe cold air of Lefkos retains its bite.＂
＂Perhaps it is this cold that keeps sleep a\nstranger. On such nights, Nadia makes tea\nand we share old memories.＂
＂Without fail, the first to surface is of when\nyou and I traveled together so you might\nsee the world before your coronation.＂

＂Oh, but we saw wonders, old friend.
Ancient ruins! The heart of the Faewood!
I shall never forget the thrill and awe
those days brought to me.＂
＂Yet it all feels an age ago. As time's\nrelentless march continued, we became\nboth kings and fathers.＂
ANOTHER letter? Let me just guess\nwho it's for this time.
I knew it! You two have been trading\nletters since you first met as boys.
We're old comrades in arms—and pals in\nmischief before that. But enough of me, girl.\nWas there aught you needed?
I just baked a tart and thought perhaps\nyou'd enjoy a slice.
I certainly would. *munch* So you've\nturned your skills to baking now, eh?
Yes, I asked the chef to let me borrow the\nkitchen for a while. How does it taste?
Before this, you were tending a vegetable\ngarden, and previous to that was your\nstint with furniture repair.
I can't say any of them are especially royal\npursuits, but you certainly seem to enjoy\ncollecting new hobbies.
They're just more practical than singing\nand dancing. Besides, cultivating a broad\nset of skills opens more opportunities, no?
You were never one to be tied down by\nconvention. I daresay you inherited that\nparticular foible from me.

Apologies, Your Majesty, but we've
received reports from the southern
checkpoint that a large crowd of
foreigners is seeking entry.
Likely refugees from Barthe whose towns\nhave burned in the war. Your orders?
Open the gates and let them in, then tell\nthe others I'll be holding council to\ndevelop a resettlement plan.
More people have come here fleeing\ntheir own countries. It's so sad.
Lefkos owes its peace to our neutrality.\nOurs is one of precious few places in\nthe north not torn apart by war.
They see hope in our kingdom and risk\ntheir lives to reach our gates. I welcome\na people so brave and determined.
That is my decision both as Lefkos's king,\nand as a human being who has tasted\nthe cruel bite of pain and loss.
Father, might I help with the\nresettlement planning?
I am part of Lefkos's royal family as well,\nand your daughter above that.
That you are indeed. Thank you, Sheila.\nYou aid will be most welcome. Come.
Until then, Lefkos had been a peaceful place.\nBut as knowledge spread of the rare resources\nin our lands, the kingdom found itself a target.
Another incursion! Those vultures won't\nstop until Lefkos is picked bare...
Which is why it falls on us to stop them.\nSteel yourself, for our people's peace\nand prosperity rest upon your shoulders.
Raise your heads and blades high,\nsoldiers of Lefkos, and fight to the last!

But even as I rallied my troops, a strange black
mana began to spread across the kingdom.
Tasked with fighting a second war against frenzied
fiends, our army was gradually worn down.

And when exhaustion finally brought us to our
nadir, Lefkos's covetous neighbors were all too
eager to strike. Soon, my once lovely kingdom
was turned into a sea of fire.
Don't speak, Nadia! Save your strength!
Fie, the wound is deep... But be at ease,\nmy child. I'll get you through this, I swear.
The enemy is almost upon us!\n...Hold on to me, girl, tight as you can.\nWe have to move.
As my country fell to ash around me, I could do\nno more than carry my daughter and run.
We hid in the forest along with what few\nsurvivors remained. But Sheila...
Lefkos has fallen, for I lacked the strength\nand wisdom to protect it.
It isn't your fault, Father... You fought to...\nto keep us all safe...
I will always be...so proud of you...
Open your eyes, my dear child!\nI cannot bear to lose you as well!
In that moment of despair, I looked up to see a\nsingle butterfly and was reminded of the past.
(Yes... He might be able to save her!)
(The king of the Faerie Kingdom...\nThe scholar of secret arts...)
I fear I must pay an old friend a visit.\nI only pray he can save Sheila's life.
If you would yet heed my wishes, I bid you\nall to survive. Find some place of peace to\nbegin your lives anew.
All of us here believed Lefkos to be\nthat place of peace...
And with the kingdom lost, Your Majesty,\nI find all hope of peace abandoned with it.\nWhere are we even to go?
I stand before you with no answer to give.\nI pray you might forgive your failed king.
As their king, it was my solemn duty to guide\nthose lost people onward—but I could not turn\nmy heart from its task.
I placed Sheila's cold body upon my back and\nmade for the Faewood, pinning what faint scraps\nof hope I still retained upon its king, Finlorda.
